newsitem.title: USA: Tampa, Fla., may sell troubled aquarium - paper.
newsitem.headline: Tampa, Fla., may sell troubled aquarium - paper.

text.p: Tampa is considering selling the struggling Florida Aquarium, and may soon issue requests for proposals from buyers, the Tampa Tribune said Friday.
Mayor Dick Greco said the city is willing to either sell the facility or help develop land around it to help draw visitors.
Greco told the newspaper he has shown the property to at least three developers, plus representatives of Busch Gardens although no formal talks have been held.
"We're certainly going to look at whatever they put forth," said Busch Gardens spokeswoman Lisa Laus.

The nonprofit aquarium was built two years ago with bonds backed by the Tampa Port Authority. When the attraction failed to attract enough visitors to cover operations and debt service, the city took over ownership and issued $104 million or revenue bonds to refinance the debt in October.

The refinancing calls for the city to pay $4.3 million annually in debt service. Despite deep cuts in aquarium staff, the city may still have to contribute an additional $2 million this year to cover operating losses.
Officials said they may seek sales or property tax concessions to make the aquarium more attracative to private interests.
